Revising my estimates after looking at the bigger, external, picture. Using the 1st July demonstrations by Hong Kongers as a y-o-y sentiment indicator, it is being observed that while the number of protesters is still lower than the numbers shown in 2003, the number of arrests has been relatively increasing. This indicates that the air is heating up between Hong Kongers and the main govt of China. While in 2003 there was a record number of almost 500k on July 1st, I could not find any records quoting any arrests.  In 2020, however, with "tens of thousands" showing up for the protests (keeping in mind COVID-19 pandemic restrictions as a background) there were over 370 arrests reported. I worked out a weighted average to extrapolate the turnout for 2020 using previous years, and I am assuming a figure of ~82,000 protestors. The ratio of arrests is therefore 0.45%, against the 0% of 2003 when the numbers where much bigger. And while the trend of arrests is going up, the sense of freedom is in decline (https://multimedia.scmp.com/infographics/news/hong-kong/article/3016815/hong-kong-protest-city/index.html). With some simple arithmetic extrapolations I am estimating that for this year's July 1st march, ~173k protestors will show up and ~840 will be arrested, indicating a heated confrontation. Using the same argument in my previous forecast, the trigger for the confrontation will be if and when Hong Kongers attack the PLA/PAP. If the numbers and reasoning above are right, there is a high probability that this will be the case on July 1st.  I therefore adjusted the weights of my 2 player graph as follows: 1. Protestors will definitely not step back if the PAP/PLA show confrontation
2. Protestors have more pay-off to attack, with rising arrests and attempts to curb freedoms from mainland govt I therefore put a 71% on the Yes.

I plotted this as a "standard" game theory 2 player graph, with the PAP/PLA and Hong Kong Protesters being the 2 players. Every player can either attack, or step back. I gave the following pay-offs: 		                      Protestors	
		                 Attack	Step back
PAP/PLA	Attack	10,5	20,0
	Step back	10,5	30,30 I thought that both have their highest pay-offs if they keep a step back, as China will surely harm its reputation should PAP/PLA attack Hong Kongers, and Hong Kongers would surely suffer if they were to be attacked by the Chinese military. In the case of Attacking - should both be attacking, the military would have the upper hand - but the protesters will be strengthening their case. Anyone who Attacks while the other steps-back, will always see the Military as winning - though totally hands down should the Hong Kongers remain idle. This took me to a 50-50 tie for the time being.

I believe it is unlikely that China will use either the PLA or PAP to confront Hong Kongers in Hong Kong. The primary reason I do not believe this will occur is because of the upcoming olympics in 2022. If the PRC uses military/para-military forces to quell anti-government protestors, it is likely that the United States (and many of its allies) would boycott the 2022 Olympic games [1]. While the protests in Hong Kong are frowned upon by the PRC, a boycotted Olympics would be a much larger black-eye for China's short and long-term interests/goals. Thus, I predict a 0% chance that the PRC will use the PLA or PAP to engage in a confrontation with anti-government protestors in Hong Kong. [1] https://www.latimes.com/politics/story/2021-04-06/us-considers-boycott-2022-olympics

Factors making this unlikely: seems like protest activity has almost completely died off, at its peak it was only Hong Kong police so it might take a lot for military involvement to happen, new laws have been passed and a general crackdown makes renewed protests seem unlikely, COVID may make renewed protests less likely as well, and recent jailing of protest leadership may create more fear and make renewed protests harder. I'm going a bit higher than the crowd because I think the factors making this more likely are plausible and it seems possible to me that even a small flare up in protesting could be met by the military as a way to instill fear. 1 in 10 chance seems appropriate.

Hong Kong residents may be held liable for any speech or action deemed secessionist, subversive, terrorist or perceived as colluding with hostile foreign political groups or individuals. Only 20 of the 90 Legislative Council members will be elected directly.
Many arrests have been made with potential life sentences.
High profile media tycoon Jimmy Lai and other leading pro-democracy advocates were sentenced to 18 months for organising demonstrations indicating an unprecedented crackdown by the Hong Kong and Beijing authorities.
The UK has introduced a special visa program to allow a potential 300,000 Hong Kong people to emigrate.
The PLA (Hong Kong garrison) conducted a military drill involving multiple services in Hong Kong that could be perceived as a signal of their presence.

(Inside view)
It's not in the interest of the mainland government for the PLA/PAP to start a fight with people in Hong Kong. The Chinese government wants stability. If the HK government needs to preserve order they'll just use the police. There's one PLA base in HK. What *could* happen is that some people might get bold enough to harass the PLA, and enter a "confrontation". But this seems highly unlikely to me because (1) this didn't happen during the period of unrest from 2019-2020 IIRC, (2) the unrest has died down (and the opposition is exhausted), and (3) people don't want to get shot.
China will succeed using other more discrete control methods, like arrests, vigilance and threats
